articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Across the African continent, many first-born children in poor and vulnerable households do not go to school as they spend their school days collecting biomass fuel. The regional average of the amount of time spent collecting firewood is 2.1 hours, robbing women and girls in particular of hundreds of hours in a year and crippling their capacities to engage in learning and productive activities.

Read the full story, “Electrifying Cooking: Decarbonizing Africa's Electricity Grid Towards Net Zero”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Electrifying Cooking: Decarbonizing Africa's Electricity Grid Towards Net Zero

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Women bear the brunt of the climate crisis, and inclusion at both the highest level and in the community is key to mitigating its impact. Today, the announcement of the COP28 Gender Responsive Just Transitions and Climate Action Partnership put women at the centre of climate solutions—with a collective endorsement that symbolized a paradigm shift in global commitment.

Read the full story, “Role of Women Irreplaceable in Management of Natural Resources”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Role of Women Irreplaceable in Management of Natural Resources

articles.description:
YEREVAN, Armenia, Dec 05 (IPS) - Every evening, the smell of Indian food takes over Yerevan's northwestern district of Halabian. Indian workers who left early in the morning are back home.

Read the full story, “A Little India in Little Armenia”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Little India in Little Armenia

articles.description:
London/New York, Dec 05 (IPS) - “The one international language the world understands” wrote Eglantyne Jebb, founder of Save the Children, “is the cry of a child,” and the evidence is accumulating that children are not only the innocent victims of conflict whose pleas need to be heard, but also the most vulnerable victims of climate change.

Read the full story, “The Climate Crisis is an Education Crisis”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Climate Crisis is an Education Crisis

articles.description:
BRATISLAVA, Dec 05 (IPS) - A major advocacy group has demanded an overhaul of global drug policies as a landmark report is released showing how governments’ complacency has perpetuated a failed ‘war on drugs’ despite its devastating consequences for millions of people around the world.

Read the full story, “'War on Drugs' Failed and Policies Need Major Overhaul - Report”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: 'War on Drugs' Failed and Policies Need Major Overhaul - Report

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Aditi Agarwal, a brilliant computer science engineer and Gold Medalist, once thrived in the tech world, contributing to innovations at Microsoft. However, she felt a calling to address real-world challenges, particularly those related to carbon emissions and plastic pollution. In pursuit of a nobler cause, she joined a company called Go Rewise, a youth-led initiative in India dedicated to recycling PET bottles through a circular economy approach.

Read the full story, “Taking Charge Against Plastic Pollution in India”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Taking Charge Against Plastic Pollution in India

articles.description:
GAZA, Palestine, Dec 05 (IPS) - The 7-day ceasefire brought respite to everyone; hostages were reunited with their families and desperately needed aid went into Gaza. We need more of this; all hostages released and considerably more aid and protection for Palestinian civilians.

Read the full story, “Nowhere is Safe in Gaza -- and Nowhere Left to Go”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Nowhere is Safe in Gaza -- and Nowhere Left to Go

articles.description:
JOHANNESBURG & TASHKENT, Dec 05 (IPS) - Successful city planning, which takes place with the involvement of citizens, is the hallmark of the creation of sustainable cities, the International Conference on Demographic Resilience heard.

Read the full story, “People, Planning Behind Sustainable City Management”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: People, Planning Behind Sustainable City Management

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Dec 05 (IPS) - The language used in the Treaty of the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) is unambiguous on its focus of the grave humanitarian impact of nuclear weapons. The TPNW also recognizes the influence of the public conscience “in the furthering of the principles of humanity as evidenced by the call for total elimination of nuclear weapons”.

Read the full story, “The Intergenerational Impact of Nuclear Testing in Polynesian States”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Intergenerational Impact of Nuclear Testing in Polynesian States

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Food and agriculture is a top agenda item at UNFCCC COP28, as the world considers how to tackle the climate impacts of what we eat and how we produce it. The stage has been set for COP28 to be a “food COP”, but for commitments to translate to action, it must also be a “farmers’ COP”.

Read the full story, “Why the UN COP28 Climate Talks Must Serve Farmers to Achieve a Just Transition”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Why the UN COP28 Climate Talks Must Serve Farmers to Achieve a Just Transition

articles.description:
WASHINGTON DC, Dec 04 (IPS) - The International Energy Agency now projects oil, gas, and coal use will all peak this decade. This constitutes a dramatic shift from the last 150 years when the thirst for fossil fuels persistently rose. But now this growth is nearing its end sooner than many expected, driven in part by a surge in renewables.

Read the full story, “From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 04 (IPS) - Pacific people live at the nexus of oceans, climate, and food systems, and the interaction of climate and ocean is raising sea temperatures and threatening habitats and resources vital to the region’s sustenance, Palau’s President Surangel Whipps, Jr., said at the launch of an effort to protect and rejuvenate the region's ecosystems and empower communities through to the year 2050—in what is considered to be the biggest single conservation effort in history—Unlocking Blue Pacific Prosperity.

Read the full story, “Pacific Leaders Announce Largest Conservation Effort in History”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Pacific Leaders Announce Largest Conservation Effort in History

articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec 04 (IPS) - This year’s UN Climate Change Conference is taking place in Dubai from 30 November to 12 December. The so-called COP summits are organised every year and constitute a means for the global community to agree on ways to address the climate crisis, such as limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, supporting vulnerable communities to adapt to the effects of climate change, and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

Read the full story, “A Climate Scientist’s View of COP 28”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Climate Scientist’s View of COP 28

articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nepal, Dec 04 (IPS) - If there is an agency or program within the UN that I really admire and wish the best for, this is the United Nation Volunteers or UNV. Its overarching mission, mandate and key objectives are paramount for humanity.

Read the full story, “UN Volunteers and Their Over Reaching Mission”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UN Volunteers  and Their Over Reaching Mission

articles.description:
LONDON, Dec 04 (IPS) - The Netherlands is the latest country to lurch to the right amid the global cost of living crisis. Its November election saw maverick far-right populist Geert Wilders and his Party for Freedom (PVV) come first. A hardline Islamophobe who’s called for the Quran to be banned could be the next prime minister.

Read the full story, “Netherlands Latest Country to Tilt to the Right”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Netherlands Latest Country to Tilt to the Right

articles.description:
JOHANNESBURG & TASHKENT, Dec 04 (IPS) - Lawmakers were reminded of the benefits of long-term planning and the benefits of evidence-based decision-making in policymaking while grappling with demographic trends, be they an aging population or one with significant growth in youth, like that of Uzbekistan.

Read the full story, “Lawmakers Told: Plan From the Cradle For Healthy Aging”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Lawmakers Told: Plan From the Cradle For Healthy Aging

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 04 (IPS) - Across the globe, the number of crisis-affected school-aged children facing climate shocks amplified by climate change keeps rising. The Somalia region of Ethiopia is facing the worst drought in 40 years. Last year in Pakistan, unprecedented flooding damaged more than 26,000 schools. Tropical Cyclone Tej recently made landfall in Yemen, affecting thousands of people.

Read the full story, “ECWs Emergency Appeal for Crises Impacted Children Facing Double Tragedies”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ECWs Emergency Appeal for Crises Impacted Children Facing Double Tragedies

articles.description:
The UN team investigating crimes committed by Da’esh terrorist group has issued its latest report documenting the terrorist group’s atrocities in Iraq, laying the groundwork for future prosecutions.

Read the full story, “Iraq: UN team issues latest report on terrorist atrocities”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Iraq: UN team issues latest report on terrorist atrocities

articles.description:
UN Secretary-General António Guterres has reiterated his call for a sustained humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza and the unconditional and immediate release of all hostages, his Spokesperson said on Monday.

Read the full story, “UN chief calls on Israel to ‘spare civilians from more suffering’ in Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UN chief calls on Israel to ‘spare civilians from more suffering’ in Gaza

articles.description:
Flooding in Somalia has uprooted more than one million people and killed 110, UN humanitarians in the country said in their latest situation report on Monday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Somalia floods, Sudan cholera update, genocide prevention”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Somalia floods, Sudan cholera update, genocide prevention

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
SUBSCRIBER+EXCLUSIVE REPORTING — In the days after Hamas fighters launched a terrorist attack in Israel in October, an illicit amphetamine known as Captagon was reportedly found in [...] More 
The post How the Captagon Trade is Bolstering Iran and its Web of Militias appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: How the Captagon Trade is Bolstering Iran and its Web of Militias
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Middle East News: Israel forces stormed southern Gaza's main city on Tuesday in what they called the most intense day of combat in five weeks of ground operations again.
articles.title: Israel storms main city of south Gaza, killing scores

articles.description: A passenger bus lost control in Hamtic town, Antique province, and plunged into a ravine, killing at least 16 people and injuring 12 others. The accident occurred on a mountain road known for accidents. The driver, who was among the casualties, lost control of the bus, which then smashed onto a concrete railing and fell into the ravine. Rescuers, including police and army troops, worked overnight to extricate the victims.
articles.title: At least 16 dead and 12 injured as passenger bus falls off ravine in central Philippines

articles.description: US President Joe Biden praised Liz Cheney's warning about the threat of a second Trump term. He also mentioned the Atlantic magazine, Washington Post, and New York Times for issuing similar warnings. Biden cited Trump's extreme language on the campaign trail, comparing it to Adolf Hitler's rise in the 1930s. Despite facing criminal trials, including one for election subversion, Trump is narrowly ahead in opinion polls. Some Democrats have called for Biden to step aside for a new candidate.
articles.title: US President Joe Biden 'not sure' he'd be seeking reelection if not for Donald Trump

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Doug Olson of Mill Woods, Edmonton, stumbled upon a small meteorite while cleaning out his rain gutters this spring. The Menisa meteorite, as it is now named, weighs 33 grams and is only the 18th ever found in Alberta. The discovery began when Olson heard a loud thud on his roof and found the small rock while clearing out his rain gutters. The meteorite is composed of iron, nickel, and chondrule, a grey material. A portion of it is now part of the University of Alberta's collection
articles.title: Edmonton resident discovers rare meteorite in rain gutter

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Conservative MP Bob Seely plans to introduce a bill to strip Prince Harry and Meghan Markle of their royal titles, citing damage to the monarchy's reputation. The proposed Titles Deprivation 1917 Act Amendment Bill draws inspiration from historical precedents and would allow a parliamentary vote to advise the Privy Council on removing titles. This move follows controversies surrounding Omid Scobie's book, which allegedly names King Charles III in a comment about Prince Archie's skin tone.
articles.title: Race row gets bigger : Meghan and Harry could soon lose Royal titles

articles.description: Middle East News: WASHINGTON: In a rare punitive move against Israel, the State Department said Tuesday it will impose travel bans on extremist Jewish settlers implicat.
articles.title: In rare action against Israel, US says extremist West Bank settlers will be barred from America

articles.description: Elon Musk, the billionaire owner of the social network X, shared a video Tuesday in which Argentina's President-elect Javier Milei says equality should never come before freedom, in a sign of how some notable conservatives are closely watching the incoming libertarian head of state. "We need to talk, Elon," Milei replied on X, formerly Twitter. This is not the first time that Musk, the founder of SpaceX and CEO of Tesla, has expressed support for Milei on social media. "Prosperity is about to come to Argentina," Musk wrote when Milei won the election runoff on Nov 19.
articles.title: Argentina's President-elect Milei replies to Musk's interest: 'We need to talk, Elon'

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson renews call for action, urging President Biden to address concerns over Ukraine strategy and immigration policy changes. White House budget director Shalanda Young warns that U.S. aid for Ukraine will run out by the end of the year. House Republicans, under Johnson's leadership, pass a bill providing security assistance only for Israel, coupled with cuts to the IRS budget. The impasse on funding could result in Russia gaining an advantage in ongoing conflict
articles.title: 'Putin could win': Johnson slams Biden's Ukraine funding strategy

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: FBI Director Christopher Wray testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee expressing deep concerns about the unprecedented level of terror threats facing the United States since the October 7 attack on Israel. Wray highlighted the unique and alarming situation in the current "threat matrix." In a related development, he urged the Senate committee to renew the authority of the U.S. government for warrantless surveillance outside the country.
articles.title: FBI director warns of unprecedented terror threats

articles.description: WASHINGTON: US President Joe Biden's popularity was near its lowest level of his presidency this month, a sign of the challenges ahead for his re-elec.
articles.title: Biden approval near lowest level of his presidency

articles.description: Saudi Arabia offers tax incentives to foreign companies locating regional headquarters in the kingdom, including a 30-year exemption for corporate income tax. The move is part of efforts by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to diversify the economy and create new industries. The tax exemption package includes a zero percent income tax rate for regional entities and withholding tax on approved activities for 30 years. The program has attracted 200 foreign companies so far, and Saudi Arabia looks forward to welcoming more international companies to participate in projects and major events.
articles.title: Saudi Arabia offers tax breaks for companies moving regional HQs to Riyadh

articles.description: Rest of World News: GENEVA: Countries need to increase their taxes on alcohol and sugar-sweetened beverages, the World Health Organization said Tuesday, saying too few st.
articles.title: WHO says time to hike alcohol, sugary drinks tax

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Despite an overall decrease in juvenile cases, young people in the Twin Cities are engaging in a growing number of severe crimes, including auto thefts, gun possession, assault, robbery, and homicides involving juveniles. Hennepin County Sheriff Dawanna Witt expressed deep concern, stating that the nature of these crimes goes beyond petty theft. Local leaders are addressing this trend through a panel that aims to enhance how state and county agencies assist young individuals charged with crimes.
articles.title: Alarming surge in serious juvenile crimes grips Minneapolis–Saint Paul

articles.description: LONDON: Lawyers for Prince Harry on Tuesday began a legal challenge over his security arrangements in the UK, after he quit frontline royal duties and.
articles.title: Prince Harry in UK court battle over security

articles.description: US News: WASHINGTON: US employers posted 8.
articles.title: US job openings fall to lowest level since March 2021 as labor market cools

articles.description: Malala Yousafzai condemns Taliban rule in Afghanistan, calling it a gender apartheid that has made girlhood illegal. She highlights the negative impact on Afghan girls who are denied education, leading to depression, drug use, and suicide attempts. Malala urges the international community to recognize gender apartheid as a crime against humanity and include it in a new UN treaty on crimes against humanity. She emphasizes the need to draw attention to the treatment of women and girls in Afghanistan, which has been overshadowed by crises in other parts of the world.
articles.title: Taliban rule 'made girlhood illegal', says Malala

articles.description: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky appeals to US senators for support ahead of funding showdown with Russia. White House warns that aid will run out by the end of the year. Zelenskyy's address highlights the importance of defending democracy and preventing Putin from winning the war. Zelenskyy's chief of staff, defense minister, and speaker of Ukraine's parliament engage in a lobbying effort in Washington. Senate Republicans condition their support for funding on immigration reforms, which Democrats have rejected.
articles.title: Zelenskyy to appeal to US senators ahead of vote on Ukraine aid

articles.description: Zambia's president remains hopeful as rescue efforts continue for at least 25 informal miners trapped in a mudslide at Seseli Mine. The mine was previously owned by Vedanta's Konkola Copper Mines (KCM) but is now under the control of a local company. The miners were trapped in three locations and heavy rains have flooded the pit. The government is working to save the lives of the trapped miners, with rescue workers being cautious due to soft ground.
articles.title: Zambia's president hopeful that trapped miners still alive

articles.description: Europe News: BUDAPEST: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban will meet French President Emmanuel Macron in Paris on Thursday, his press chief said, ahead of an EU .
articles.title: Hungary's Orban to meet Macron ahead of EU summit

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Trevor D. Jacob, a YouTuber known for staging a plane crash, has been sentenced to prison for obstructing the investigation. He intentionally crashed his plane for his YouTube channel, misleading investigators and removing the wreckage. The U.S. Attorney's Office stated that Jacob's motive was to gain notoriety and make money. Jacob's sentencing was handed down by Judge John F. Walter. His YouTube video contributed to his FAA pilot license revocation.
articles.title: YouTuber lands in jail for staging plane crash in California for views

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Scientists have discovered the Lost City Hydrothermal Field, an otherworldly environment with towering structures and a thriving ecosystem. This hydrothermal field is located close to an underwater mountain west of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. It features creamy carbonate towers, some up to 60 meters tall. The Lost City is unique because it has sustained its existence for at least 120,000 years and contains hydrocarbons formed on the deep seafloor....
articles.title: Scientists uncover 'Lost City' beneath Atlantic Ocean

articles.description: Alaska Airlines announces intent to purchase Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, awaiting regulatory approval. Merger would create nation's fifth-largest carrier, with combined fleet of 365 aircraft serving 138 destinations. Potential benefits include expanded connections to U.S., Asia, and the Pacific. Regulatory scrutiny expected due to reduced competition in Hawaii. Acquisition reflects industry trend of consolidation to navigate financial challenges.
articles.title: Alaska Airlines to acquire Hawaiian Airlines in $1.9 billion deal

articles.description: Pakistan's Election Commission has asked the government to deploy regular army troops to ensure security during the general election scheduled for February 8, 2024. The commission stated that the provincial police force is insufficient, requiring at least 591,106 security personnel. There is a shortage of 277,558 police personnel in the provinces and federation. The demand for army deployment is not new in Pakistan. The caretaker Information Minister assured that the government will provide the necessary funds, as approved by the Cabinet, for the Election Commission's needs. Finance Secretary Imdadullah Bosal confirmed that the funds will be released within two days.
articles.title: Pakistan's election body asks govt to deploy army on general election day

articles.description: EU envoys meet to debate membership talks with Ukraine, despite Hungary's threat to block. Decisions on integration prospects for Moldova, Georgia, and Bosnia also expected at the summit. Hungary argues that Ukraine is not ready due to corruption and ongoing conflict. Hungary's concerns may complicate negotiations. Other EU countries seek to advance the prospects of Georgia and Bosnia in exchange for supporting Ukraine. EU aid to Hungary has been unlocked to sway Budapest's decision.
articles.title: EU states to start debating Ukraine membership talks on Tuesday

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Joan Donovan, a disinformation scholar, accuses Harvard University of infringing on her free speech by dismissing her, potentially to appease Facebook. Donovan's termination, allegedly linked to Harvard's $500 million pledge from Meta founder Mark Zuckerberg, is seen as compromising academic freedom and prioritizing the interests of the tech giant. Harvard denies Donovan's claims, asserting that she was a staff employee and offering her a part-time role, which she declined.
articles.title: Harvard accused of favouring Facebook by disinformation scholar

articles.description: Tanzanian Prime Minister Kassim Majaliwa pays tribute to the 63 people killed in landslides and flooding in Katesh. The toll is expected to rise. Torrential downpours caused the disaster, washing away vehicles and buildings. Rescue operations are underway with the help of the military. The floods exacerbate the humanitarian crisis in the region, which is recovering from a severe drought. The president has cut short her visit to Dubai for the COP28 climate talks.
articles.title: Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 63

articles.description: Putin discussed disrupted cooperation between Moscow and Berlin due to the blasts in September 2022 that affected the Nord Stream pipelines. He mentioned this during a ceremony in the Kremlin while accepting new foreign ambassadors. Putin emphasized that the current frozen state of relations is unprofitable for both countries, especially Germany. He highlighted that energy cooperation was disrupted by the sabotage on the Nord Stream pipelines. Russia has accused the United States, Britain, and Ukraine of the pipeline blasts, but they have all denied any involvement. Putin also expressed hope for improved relations between Moscow and London.
articles.title: Putin blames Nord Stream blasts for disruption of Russia-Germany relations

articles.description: A Kenyan court on Monday suspended a government plan to start a fresh privatisation drive under a modified law while it hears a challenge that an opposition party has brought against the sales. In late November the finance ministry said it would start the process of offering to sell its shareholding in 11 firms, including an oil pipeline, a textbook publisher and agribusiness firms. The 11 companies are among more than 35 companies that are lined up for sale, partly to help the government raise revenue in the face of growing debt repayments.
articles.title: Kenyan court suspends plan to privatise more state-owned firms

articles.description: Argentina's president-elect Javier Milei appoints Rodolfo Barra, a former justice minister, as the attorney general of the treasury. Barra's appointment has sparked controversy due to his past involvement in an ultranationalist movement and anti-Semitism claims. The Argentine Forum Against Anti-Semitism and opposition politicians have protested against Barra's appointment, calling it a direct affront to the democratic and plural spirit of the country. Barra had previously apologized for his past behavior, but concerns remain about his suitability for the role.
articles.title: Argentina's Milei picks former pro-Nazi youth for top legal post

articles.description: Israeli and Palestinian representatives at the UN Human Rights Council traded accusations of 'genocide' over the war in Gaza. Israel's war against Hamas and the resulting man-made catastrophe were discussed. The Israeli representative highlighted the genocidal ideology of Hamas and the online anti-Semitism faced by the Jewish people. The Palestinian representative emphasized the massive bombing campaign by Israel and called for early action under the genocide convention. Other Muslim countries accused Israel of incitement to genocide, and concerns were raised about the failure to prevent genocide and the repression of Palestinian voices online.
articles.title: Israel, Palestinians accuse each other of 'genocide' at UN

articles.description: Torrential downpours in Katesh, northern Tanzania, caused landslides and flooding, resulting in at least 57 deaths and many more trapped. President Samia Suluhu Hassan, who cut short her visit to Dubai for climate talks, confirmed the casualties. Regional commissioner Queen Sendiga initially reported 47 dead. The military is assisting with search and rescue operations as thick mud hampers efforts. The floods compound the humanitarian crisis in East Africa, which is recovering from a severe drought. Human-induced climate change is making extreme weather events more frequent and intense.
articles.title: Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 57

articles.description: Pakistan anti-corruption court summons former PM Imran Khan and wife Bushra Bibi for the Al-Qadir Trust case. Non-bailable arrest warrants issued for six others, including Malik Riaz Hussain, in the Al-Qadir Trust corruption case. Judge orders Khan's production from Adiala Jail and directs Bibi to appear. Next hearing to be held at Adiala Jail. Charges allege Khan and Bibi obtained billions of rupees and land from Bahria Town Ltd to legalize Rs50 billion returned from the UK.
articles.title: Pakistan court summons Imran Khan, wife on December 6 in Al-Qadir case

articles.description: Israeli authorities are investigating claims that some investors may have profited from Israeli securities by short-selling shares based on advance knowledge of a Hamas plan to attack Israel. Law professors Robert Jackson Jr and Joshua Mitts found significant short-selling of the MSCI Israel ETF and Israeli securities on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange leading up to the attacks. The matter is under investigation by the Israel Securities Authority and relevant parties. The researchers also discovered a sharp increase in trading of risky short-dated options on Israeli companies just before the attacks.
articles.title: Israel investigates possible trading knowledge ahead of October 7 Hamas attack

articles.description: At least 83 Spanish media outlets had filed a USD 598 million lawsuit against Meta platforms for unfair competition in the advertising market. The AMI newspaper filed a lawsuit with the media association. The newspapers said Meta's "massive" and "systematic" use of personal data from the users of its Facebook, Instagram, and Whatsapp platforms allows it to get an unfair advantage in designing and offering personalized ads that constitute unfair competition.
articles.title: Spanish media association files $598 million lawsuit against Facebook owner Meta

articles.description: Harvard University faces alumni dissatisfaction and a substantial decline in donations due to concerns over the handling of a campus crisis, including reports of antisemitism. The university's fundraising operation, which relies on volunteers, is struggling to assuage these concerns while maintaining financial support. The financial impact of this alumni revolt is uncertain, but it poses a reputational risk and could have a significant effect on Harvard's annual revenue.
articles.title: Why many alums are making just $1 donations to Harvard

articles.description: Narges Mohammadi, the jailed Iranian Nobel Peace Prize winner, vows to continue her fight for human rights, even if it means risking her life. Currently serving multiple sentences in Tehran's Evin prison, she is accused of spreading propaganda against the Islamic Republic. Her imprisonment and psychological torture have not deterred her. She started a hunger strike to protest the prison's lack of medical care. In a letter smuggled out from prison, she expresses her longing for her children.
articles.title: Jailed Nobel winner Mohammadi to continue protests, she says in smuggled letter

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Residents of Scranton, Pennsylvania, offer a spectrum of opinions on President Biden's recent claim to view the U.S. economy through their eyes. Critical voices express skepticism and criticize Biden as the worst president. Local leaders express sentiments through controversial roadway renamings. Varied opinions question Biden's connection to Scranton, with some uncertainty about the 2024 race. Scranton residents criticize the state of the economy and express weariness with political scandals.
articles.title: Biden's hometown speaks: Scranton residents 'critical' of 'Bidenomics'

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: U.S. and Japanese rescuers discover wreckage and identify remains of crew members from crashed Osprey aircraft. U.S. Air Force reports breakthrough in recovery efforts, retrieving main fuselage and remains. Crash prompts suspension of flights for Japan's Osprey fleet. Identification of remains underway. Incident reignites discussions about Japan-U.S. Status of Forces Agreement. Tragedy raises questions about crash cause and safety of Osprey aircraft.
articles.title: US military discovers remains of five Osprey crash victims off Japan's coast

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: China accuses US of violating sovereign waters in South China Sea; USS Gabrielle Giffords allegedly illegally intruded near Second Thomas Shoal; Chinese naval force monitors American warship's movements; Philippines seeks American assistance in territorial conflicts; China accuses US of meddling in the region, escalating tensions; USS Gabrielle Giffords becomes focal point of dispute; China insists on its right over the South China Sea; concerns over potential for further military confrontations
articles.title: US denies China's allegations of naval intrusion in the South China Sea

articles.description: Britain's armed forces face a funding shortfall of 17 billion pounds over the next 10 years, the largest deficit since 2012. The budget for new weapons and equipment is estimated at 305.5 billion pounds for 2023-2033, 16.9 billion pounds over budget. Soaring costs in nuclear and naval programs, as well as high inflation, have pushed up the future budget. The Ministry of Defence's financial position has deteriorated. Russia's war in Ukraine has highlighted the need for extra military spending across Europe, with Britain as an important ally and provider of military equipment to Kyiv.
articles.title: UK military faces $22 billion equipment shortfall, watchdog says

articles.description: A bomb attack on a Catholic mass in Marawi, Philippines, at Mindanao State University's gymnasium left at least four dead and dozens wounded. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the blast, which occurred during a morning service. The explosion was caused by an improvised explosive device. The university condemned the violence and suspended classes, while the city's mayor called for unity among Muslim and Christian communities.
articles.title: Four killed in bomb attack on Catholic mass in Philippines

articles.description: MANILA: A magnitude 6.
articles.title: Magnitude 6.9 earthquake strikes off southern Philippines: USGS

articles.description: A man went on a knife attack, killing four relatives, including two children, at their New York City home. He then set the building on fire and stabbed two police officers before being shot. The incident occurred in Far Rockaway, Queens. The police officers were responding to a 911 call from a young female who reported her cousin was killing her family. The suspect, identified as Courtney Gordon, had been visiting the family from the Bronx. This incident follows a similar knife rampage in the Bronx last week.
articles.title: Man kills 4 relatives in Queens knife rampage, injures 2 officers before he's fatally shot by police

articles.description: Israeli PM Netanyahu discusses ongoing hostage release efforts in Gaza, emphasizing strategic decision-making. He urges caution among Likud ministers, calls for unity and focus on all fronts. Netanyahu expresses the need for a thorough inquiry into the shooting incident involving Yuval Doron Castleman, a hero who tragically lost his life. The incident prompts public outcry, leading to the involvement of the IDF in the investigation. The situation remains tense as Israel addresses security concerns and continues military operations to secure the release of hostages.
articles.title: 'Speaking with Fire': Benjamin Netanyahu affirms ongoing talks with Hamas on hostage release

articles.description: US officials to visit Pakistan in December for consultations on various issues including the ongoing situation in Afghanistan; both countries exchanging visits to speed up the process; Pakistan blames Afghanistan for terrorist attacks and usage of Afghan oil for attacks; recent attack resulted in casualties; Pakistan deporting illegal Afghan citizens; US Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration to visit Pakistan; discussions not limited to Afghanistan concerns.
articles.title: US officials to visit Pakistan in December to discuss Afghanistan, other issues

articles.description: Israel struck Gaza targets in its war on Hamas. The civilian death toll increased, causing international concern. More than 15,500 people have been killed in the Palestinian territory. Israeli air and artillery strikes hit Gaza, while rockets were launched from Gaza into Israel. The UN reported 160 Palestinian deaths in two incidents. The Israeli army said it had carried out 10,000 air strikes, located more than 800 shafts to Hamas tunnels destroyed 500 Hamas tunnels.
articles.title: Israel bombs Gaza as pressure mounts to protect civilians

articles.description: European far-right parties gathered in Italy to strategize for the upcoming European Parliament elections. They aim to reshape the European Union by adopting tougher immigration policies and relaxing climate regulations to safeguard jobs and industry. The meeting was inspired by Geert Wilders' PVV party's unexpected success in the recent Dutch elections. Italian Deputy Prime Minister Salvini, the host, aspires for their alliance to become the third-largest group in the EU Parliament.
articles.title: Far-right parties eye gains in next year's EU parliament elections

articles.description: Italy's culture minister rejects the German State Antiquities Collection's request to return the Discobolus Palombara, a 2nd-century Roman copy of a Greek bronze statue that embodied Hitler's Aryan aesthetic. Hitler acquired the statue in 1938 against the wishes of Italian officials. The statue was returned to Italy in 1948. The dispute now involves the director of the National Roman Museum requesting the return of the statue's marble base from the German museum.
articles.title: Italy refuses Munich museum's request to return ancient Roman statue bought by Adolf Hitler

articles.description: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC), Karim Khan, announced that the ICC will intensify investigations into possible crimes committed by Hamas and Israeli forces. The ICC has been looking into crimes in the Palestinian territories since 2021, but has not yet filed any charges. Khan witnessed "scenes of calculated cruelty" during his visit to locations of the October 7 attacks by Hamas. He called for the release of hostages taken by Hamas.
articles.title: After visiting Israel and Ramallah, the ICC prosecutor says he will intensify investigations

articles.description: Guinea-Bissau's President Umaro Sissoco Embalo confirmed that the recent shootout in the capital was an attempted coup, following the improper release of two ministers detained over corruption allegations. President Embalo dismissed the head of the National Guard and warned of consequences for everyone involved. This attempted coup adds to the growing number of military takeovers in West and Central Africa. The incident has garnered deep concern from the regional economic bloc.
articles.title: Guinea-Bissau's leader calls a shootout an attempted coup, heightening tensions in West Africa

articles.description: A man wielding a steak knife killed four members of his extended family in Queens, New York City. The incident was reported by a girl in the Far Rockaway neighborhood. The suspect, a 38-year-old, stabbed two police officers who responded to the scene, but was shot dead by one of the officers. The suspect had a history of domestic violence. The police had to wait for the fire department to arrive before entering the home, as the suspect had set fire to a couch.
articles.title: Man stabs four to death in New York's Queens, police shoot him dead

articles.description: Brazilian President Lula da Silva visits Berlin for Brazilian-German government consultations to revive ties after years of diplomatic isolation. Both countries push for a quick trade deal between the EU and Mercosur. The visit highlights their differences over the Israel-Hamas war.

articles.description: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo urges lawmakers, Silicon Valley, and US allies to prevent China from acquiring semiconductors and cutting-edge technologies crucial for national security. Raimondo calls for tighter export controls, better funding to protect America's leadership in artificial intelligence and advanced semiconductor design.

articles.description: Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko, a staunch ally of Moscow, is visiting China on Sunday and Monday to meet his counterpart Xi Jinping, the Belarusian presidency said. articles.description: Ukrainian officials accuse Russian forces of killing surrendering Ukrainian soldiers. It will be a war crime if confirmed. Ukrainian energy ministry reports power outages in towns and villages due to wintry weather and ongoing fighting.

articles.description: India agrees to withdraw soldiers from the Maldives as President Mohamed Muizzu announces the decision. Indian military personnel were mainly present to operate helicopters and aircraft, assist in disaster response, and help build a naval dockyard.

articles.description: Phasing out fossil fuels has been a heated debate at the U.N. articles.description: Renowned for dependable hospitality and ritualized etiquette, Japan now has one restaurant where the service is dependably, defiantly atrocious. articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: Hamas has used “increasingly sophisticated” tactics against Israeli forces since the ceasefire in the Gaza strip ended on December 1, according to the Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a US think tank. As the conflict is increasingly focused in southern Gaza, the Palestinian Islamist group is also deploying more advanced weapons, including explosive drones and anti-tank ammunition.

articles.description: Countries at the COP28 climate conference in Dubai are considering calling for a formal phaseout of fossil fuels as part of the UN summit's final deal to tackle global warming, a draft negotiating text seen on Tuesday shows. articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, Venezuela's opposition leader Maria Corina Machado said that Sunday's referendum in Venezuela over the status of the disputed region of Essequibo was "absolutely not" the success proclaimed by the Maduro regime. According to electoral authorities, 95 percent of voters approved of Venezuela's claim to the large swath of neighbouring Guyana, but turnout was around 50 percent. Asked about the political situation in Venezuela, she said the Maduro regime was "in its weakest position ever" and that she expected to "face Maduro and defeat him" in the 2024 presidential elections.
articles.title: Venezuela opposition leader Machado: 'The Maduro regime is in its weakest position ever'

articles.description: Hebron is the richest and most populated city in the West Bank. Tensions between Israeli settlers and Palestinian locals have been on the rise there since the October 7 Hamas attacks and Israel's retaliatory air strikes on Gaza. Israeli soldiers multiply patrols in the Old City of Hebron to protect some 800 Israeli settlers who occupy houses around the Cave of the Patriarchs, a sacred shrine to both Jews and Muslims. Our reporters James Andre and Julie Dungelhoeff went to meet members of both communities.

articles.description: French feminist groups have come under fire for purportedly turning a blind eye to the sexual violence unleashed on Israeli women during the October 7 attacks by Hamas, echoing the anger levelled at rights organisations elsewhere. The accusation is indicative of the competing narratives and loyalties elicited by the devastating conflict. It also reflects a failure to rapidly investigate and establish the specific, gender-based nature of some of the atrocities committed.
articles.title: MeToo, for Israeli victims too: Gaza war drives wedge between French feminists

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
After months of mounting pressure and frustration among both lawmakers and the military brass, Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) is finally ending his protest block on over 400 military appointments and promotions, letting them all be confirmed by voice vote. He continues to hold a block on just 11 four-star generals, who could be scheduled and confirmed individually by the Senate.
Speaking to CNN congressional reporter Manu Raju, Tuberville admitted he gave up because if he waited any longer, the nominations would have been returned to the White House, causing even further chaos.
"I can’t win. I’m still thinking about the unborn, I’m thinking about the military people that need to be promoted, it’s been a year for a lot of them. It’s been a long time," said Tuberville. "I think we proved a poi…
articles.title: 'I can't win': Tuberville reveals why he gave up on his military blockade

articles.description: By Nandita Bose BOSTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Tuesday that Hamas had repeatedly raped women and mutilated their bodies during its Oct.7 assault on southern Israel, citing survivors and witnesses of the attacks. Speaking at a political fundraiser in Boston, Biden said accounts of "unimaginable cruelty" had been shared over the past few weeks. "Reports of women raped — repeatedly raped — and their bodies being mutilated while still alive, of women's corpses being desecrated, Hamas terrorists inflicting as much pain and suffering on women and girls as possible and then murde...
articles.title: Biden says Hamas raped, mutilated women during Israel assault

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The widow of a French serial killer known as the "Ogre of the Ardennes" on Tuesday admitted she played an "unforgivable" role in the 1990 rape and murder of British student Joanna Parrish by her former husband.
Confronted with images of Parrish's swollen face after her body was pulled from the river Yonne, Monique Olivier said that "it's because of me she's gone, it's unforgivable".
She remained silent in the glass-screened dock for long moments as she looked at the pictures, before pushing them away with a trembling hand.
Olivier is on trial for her role in three kidnappings and murders by her late husband Michel Fourniret and her role in rapes and attempted rape in two of the cases.
On "hunts" with her husband, Olivier said during cross-examination that "I was the dog, I was never anythi…
articles.title: Killer's wife says role in British student's death 'unforgivable'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Lawyers for Prince Harry on Tuesday began a legal challenge over his security arrangements in the UK, after he quit frontline royal duties and moved to North America. 
The case about his loss of UK taxpayer-funded protection is the latest in a string of court proceedings initiated by Harry, whose father is King Charles III.
Harry is taking legal action against the UK interior ministry over a February 2020 decision by a committee that deals with the security of members of the royal family. 
The Duke of Sussex, as he is formally known, had been told he would no longer be given the "same degree" of personal protective security that he previously enjoyed.
Shaheed Fatima, for Harry, told the High Court in London the case was about the prince's right to "safety and security". 
She added in writt…
articles.title: Prince Harry in U.K. court battle over security

articles.description: Time magazine released its shortlist for its perennial Person of the Year selection. The annual honor began in 1927 when Charles Lindbergh received the distinction following his solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean. Since then, people like Gandhi, Martin Luther King Jr., Nelson Mandela, Pope Francis and climate activist Greta Thunberg have received the honor, along with several world leaders and every president since Franklin D. Roosevelt (except Gerald Ford). The magazine has also swerved in the past and awarded “concepts,” like “The Silence Breakers” who started the MeToo movement a...
articles.title: Time’s Person of the Year 2023 shortlist includes Taylor Swift, Barbie and Putin

articles.author: Jake Johnson, Common Dreams
articles.description:
Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore said Sunday that fossil fuel interests have effectively seized the reins of the United Nations climate summit process, preventing the kind of ambitious action that scientists say is necessary to prevent catastrophic warming and all of its cascading impacts.
"This industry is way more effective at capturing politicians than they are at capturing emissions," Gore told Reuters on the sidelines of the COP28 summit in Dubai. "And they have captured the COP process itself now and overreached, abusing the public's trust by naming the CEO of one of the largest and least responsible oil companies in the world as head of the COP. It's an abuse of the public's right to have confidence in the processes by which the decisions about humanity's future are made."
Sultan …
articles.title: Al Gore says fossil fuel industry has 'captured the COP process'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
North Korean "smuggling networks" are registering ships in Pacific nations to disguise themselves while trafficking oil, according to former United Nations sanctions experts and documents obtained by AFP.
With strict sanctions limiting Pyongyang's ability to import fuel, North Korean smugglers have adopted increasingly creative methods to deceive authorities and dodge scrutiny.
These efforts, security analysts said, could be directly linked to the North's military ambitions.
"Almost none of the Pacific Islands have escaped North Korean attempts to hide their vessels," said Neil Watts, a former member of the UN Security Council's expert panel on North Korea.
The Washington-based Center for Advanced Defense Studies has been monitoring the bustling shipping lanes of the Taiwan Strait and Kore…
articles.title: North Korean smugglers disguised under Pacific island flags

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
On a sailing boat anchored off Oman's pristine Daymaniyat Islands, volunteer divers pull on wetsuits, check their scuba tanks and then take turns plunging into the clear turquoise water.
They are diving for a reason: to remove the massive fishing nets damaging an unusually resilient coral reef system that is seen as more likely than most to survive rising sea temperatures.
The clean-up is one example of how divers and Omani authorities are joining forces to protect the reefs -- which are critical for marine wildlife -- from man-made damage.
"Coral reefs are a refuge for marine habitat and wildlife," said Hammoud al-Nayri of Oman's environmental authority, as he watched the divers.
"To protect marine ecosystems, we must first preserve coral reefs," said the 45-year-old who oversees the Daym…
articles.title: Volunteer divers guard Oman's 'unique' coral reefs

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Three commercial ships in the Red Sea were struck by ballistic missiles fired from Houthi-controlled Yemen on Sunday and a U.S. warship shot down three drones in self-defense during the hourslong assault, the US military said. Responsibility for the attack was claimed by the Houthi rebels, who are backed by Iran.
The attacks marked an escalation in a series of maritime attacks in the Mideast linked to the Israel-Hamas war, as multiple vessels found themselves in the crosshairs of a single Houthi assault for the first time in the conflict.
In a statement, U.S. Central Command said the attacks “represent a direct threat to international commerce and maritime security. They have jeopardised the lives of international crews representing multiple countries around the world.” It said the three c…
articles.title: U.S. destroyer shoots down drones after Houthi attack on ships in Red Sea

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
At least 11 hikers were killed and 12 others are missing after Mount Merapi in Indonesia's West Sumatra province erupted on Sunday, triggering volcanic ash rain in several areas. 
At least 49 people have been safely evacuated after the eruption, while attempts were being made to move several others to safety, said Abdul Malik, the head of the National Search and Rescue Agency in the provincial capital, Padang. 
"Eleven people were found dead," he said.
articles.title: Indonesia's Mount Merapi erupts, 11 killed, 12 missing

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
A Philadelphia software engineer posted a video of protesters circling a falafel restaurant run by a James Beard Award winner who is Jewish. The protesters associated the chef and owner with Israel's bombing of Gaza. 
Taking to social media on Sunday, a man identifying himself as Jordan, who works for Bloomberg, posted the video and some details about what he observed. 
"Goldie, Goldie you can’t hide, we charge you with genocide," the protesters chanted. 
ALSO READ: A neuroscientist explains how evolution offers a solution for Palestine and Israel
"They continued their march down the street, but not before vandalizing the front windows," he wrote. "To clarify, I witnessed them placing stickers on the front door and windows of the restaurant. I just walked by," and the stickers read "Free Palestine" and "This is Genocide." 
"Serving falafel" is genocide? Questioned Jordan. 
Former George W. Bush speechwriter David Frum explained that the restaurant Goldie is run by Michael Solomonov, who has a number of establishments in the area bringing culinary creations from Israel to the United States. 
Calling the protesters an "antisemitic mob," Frum said, "They demand a boycott of Jewish goods. Michael Solomonov is a James Beard Award-winning chef. He makes some of the best hummus outside Israel, as well as outstanding lamb and other dishes. It all ships via Goldbelly. If you want to send a message of your own to the boycotters, you can do so here." 
Middle East expert Eli Kowaz, a policy adviser to the Israel Policy Forum, explained that Solomonov has long been an "outspoken advocate of Israeli-Palestinian peace."
Alex Zeldin, columnist at "The Forward" on U.S. Foreign Policy and Jewish communal concerns, reposted the video as well, noting that the owner of a falafel shop has no power to "anything about Israel's military campaign against Hamas. What you're looking at is people normalizing antisemitic incitement against their Jewish neighbors."
See the video below or at the link here.


 —  (@)
articles.title: Philadelphia protesters circle Jewish chef's falafel restaurant: 'You can't hide!'

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Former Ambassador and diplomat Manuel Rocha was arrested in Miami after a long-running counterintelligence investigation. 
According to the Associated Press, Rocha is being accused of working as an agent of Cuba’s government.
While more details are expected in court on Monday, those who spoke to reporters said that Rocha was working with the Cuban government to promote its interests within the United States. 
Over the past several years, the Justice Department has cracked down on individuals who have neglected to register as a foreign agent, as required by law.  
As the Washington Post explained, Rocha worked under both Democratic and Republican administrations for about 25 years. He mostly focused on Latin America during the Cold War and was posted, at one point, in Cuba when there wasn't a full diplomatic relationship with Fidel Castro.
Rocha also served as the director for Inter-American Affairs at the National Security Council in Washington under former President George H. W. Bush.
Former FBI agent Peter Strzok said of the report: "From Rocha to the Cuban 5 to Kendall and Gwendolyn Myers to Ana Montes (read about her in a new book from her FBI case agent Pete Lapp) to a remarkable run of success in running double agents, the Cuban Intelligence services are very, very good."
Read the full report at the Post.
articles.title: Former U.S. diplomat arrested in FBI spying probe

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
A columnist for the home-state newspaper of Sen. John Kennedy (R-LA) is going after the senator, saying he should know better than causing an international incident.
The Louisiana newspaper The Advocate attacked the state's U.S. senator in an op-ed Sunday by longtime columnist Stephanie Grace. Calling him a "smart man who likes to say stupid things," Grace explained that he loves hurling insults at appointees for federal office instead of questioning the individuals about their history he finds so objectionable. 
He called one Soviet-born law professor "comrade," implying he was a communist by birth. He attacks legislation to dog urine and attacks colleagues, saying, "It must suck to be that dumb."
"Clearly, Kennedy is just fine with sacrificing his senatorial dignity at the altar of ownin…
articles.title: Hometown paper begs Sen. John Kennedy not to cause an 'international incident'

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the Russian attacks in Kherson, calling them "pure terrorist attacks." 
"There were more than 20 Russian attacks in the Kherson region on this day alone," Zelensky said in his evening video address on Sunday. 
"Brutal strikes, all over the city — houses, streets, hospitals," he continued. 
At least two people were killed and seven injured in a Russian artillery attack on an apartment block in the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson on Sunday, the Ukrainian Unian news agency reported citing the regional military administrator Roman Morchko.
articles.title: Zelensky calls Russian airstrikes on Kherson 'pure terrorist attacks'

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
Israel's military is extending its ground offensive to the entire Gaza Strip, army spokesman Daniel Hagari said on Sunday evening.
The move comes about five weeks after the Israeli army started its ground offensive in the north of the Palestinian coastal enclave. 
The soldiers are taking action against targets of the Islamist group Hamas, Hagari said. 
Earlier, eyewitnesses had told news agency DPA that Israeli ground troops had advanced into an area east of the city of Khan Yunis in south Gaza.
articles.title: Israel extends ground offensive to entire Gaza Strip

articles.description:
Curtin University's Dean of Global Futures Joe Siracusa says the Biden administration has “less and less” leverage over Israel regarding the conflict in the Middle East.  

“It's not able to get the Israelis to do anything,” Mr Siracusa said. 

He said reports have shown Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has a plan to reduce the population of Gaza Palestinians to the lowest possible level. 

Mr Siracusa says the United States’ push for a two-state solution is as “dead as the dodo”. 

“We’re in a terrible place here because this can only get worse before it gets better.”
articles.title: Biden administration having ‘less and less’ leverage with Israel

articles.description: Christmas has come early for a 13-strong EuroMillions work syndicate after they landed a £1 million win. The group of waiters, office, maintenance and spa staff at Ye Olde Bell Hotel near Retford in Nottinghamshire, scooped the prize in the UK Millionaire Maker draw on Friday November 3. Members of the syndicate normally see a few small wins during the year and use the money to pay for a Christmas meal in January, having worked together throughout the festive party season.

articles.description:
French President Emmanuel Macron has called on Australia to lift its nuclear ban after the government rejected a nuclear pledge at the COP28 summit. 

The declaration to triple nuclear energy capacity globally by 2050 was endorsed by more than 20 countries at the UN climate change conference. 

When asked by 17-year-old Nuclear for Australia founder Will Shackel about nuclear energy's role in global plans to decarbonise, President Macron said he hopes Australia will manage to lift the ban. 

“Nuclear energy is a source that is necessary to succeed for carbon neutrality in 2050,” Mr Macron said. 

Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has criticised Labor, claiming the Albanese government has isolated itself from AUKUS allies by not endorsing the pledge.
articles.title: Emmanuel Macron calls on Albanese government to lift nuclear ban

Biden administration’s decision to cancel the program, announced in the 2022 Nuclear Posture Review, and it rekindled a debate on its merits.  The new missile would effectively reconstitute a retired Cold War system, the nuclear-armed version of the Tomahawk land attack cruise missile, which could strike targets at ranges of 2,500 kilometers (or roughly 1,550 miles).   While critics have rightly

articles.description:
In yet another curious twist in its long history, the Monroe Doctrine, which turned 200 on Saturday, is making an unexpected political comeback in the United States. “I think it’s as relevant today as it was the day it was written,” declared Rex Tillerson, Donald Trump’s first secretary of state, in Mexico City in 2018. More recently, contestants for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination have competed to lay claim to the doctrine. The evening of his botched campaign announcement on Twitter/X, Florida governor Ron DeSantis took to Fox News’ airwaves to call for “a 21st-century version of the Monroe Doctrine”
The post The Many Faces of the Monroe Doctrine appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: The Many Faces of the Monroe Doctrine

articles.author: Geoffrey Brasse
articles.description:
Twenty-three years after the U.N. Security Council passed the Women, Peace, and Security framework and six years after the United States became the only country to legislatively mandate its implementation, widespread misunderstanding remains about why it matters to national security. Contrary to what is sometimes heard among U.S. security practitioners in classrooms, conferences, and conversations, this is not a social justice program. It is not a diversity, equity, and inclusion mandate, or a call for the government to “do the right thing.” And regardless of what the name might make you think, it is not just about women.  Rather, the
The post Women, Peace, Security: Thinking Creatively to Pursue National Security through Gender Equality  appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Women, Peace, Security: Thinking Creatively to Pursue National Security through Gender Equality

Politico:  US officials frustrated by Biden administration’s response to attacks in Red Sea

 
Jake Sullivan said the U.S. ‘cannot assess’ a U.S. warship was targeted. 
An hourslong firefight involving U.S. commercial vessels in the Red Sea this weekend has left some U.S. officials frustrated by what they see as the Biden administration’s deliberate downplaying of a major threat to American forces.
A U.S. Navy warship scrambled to respond to multiple distress calls on Sunday, as Houthi rebels in Yemen launched missiles and drones against three separate commercial vessels. The USS Carney fired back, taking down three unmanned aerial systems.

WNU Editor: National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan is saying the U.S. ‘cannot assess’ a U.S. warship was targeted. This contradicts earlier claims from the Pentagon that the U.S. was being targeted .... Pentagon: U.S. warship, commercial ships attacked in Red Sea (AP).

articles.description:
Thomas Peter / Reuters   
Michael Schuman, The Atlantic: Why Xi Wants Trump to Win 
After four years of Joe Biden, China’s leaders would likely be relieved to have Donald Trump back in the White House. 
Compared with his predecessor, Biden has operated quietly. Trump launched a trade war; slapped tariffs on Chinese imports; and infuriated Beijing by referring to the coronavirus as “the Chinese Virus,” blaming the Chinese Communist Party for its spread, and even at times humoring theories that the party may have played a role in its creation. 
But Biden has hit China harder than Trump ever did. Armed with a more determined foreign policy, he has inflicted acute damage on the country’s economy and geopolitical ambitions, from which China’s leader, Xi Jinping, has struggled to recover. “A Biden-led U.S., probably from the Chinese perspective, looks like a more formidable challenge,” Scott Kennedy, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C., told me.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Both Michael Schuman and The Atlantic are long time opponents of former President Trump while also being vocal supporters of President Biden. They do not disappoint in the above post. 
As to what is my take. 
One of the major cornerstones of U.S. foreign policy since Nixon's trip to China in 1973 was to go to great lengths to make sure that the Soviet Union (Russia) and China never formed a political/economic/military alliance. To do so would present a clear geopolitical threat to long term US strategic national interests. 
Sighhhh ....
For the past 50 years this has been the policy. No more now. I can now say with confidence that the Biden administration has successfully blown-up this U.S. foreign policy priority. 
Bottom line. 
A President Trump is not going to change this new political/international reality. And if Biden is re-elected, it will probably accelerate it even further. In both situations President Xi is the winner, and  Xi knows that.
articles.title: Does Chinese President Xi Want Trump To Win In 2024?

A long-running spat between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and the country's top commander is breaking into public view as Kyiv seeks to shore up its battlefield and diplomatic positions under a cloud of unmet expectations. 
With freezing temperatures settling over 600 miles of churned battlefields, Ukraine is facing another difficult winter of Russian bombardment. Ukrainian officials will spend the coming months trying to shore up waning Western financial and military support, while batting away demands for renewed peace talks with Moscow.

A day after the White House warned that the United States would soon run out of money to send weapons to Ukraine, President Volodymyr Zelensky will make a direct appeal to senators on Tuesday aimed at reminding lawmakers what is at stake if they fail to quickly approve emergency military aid for his nation.

Politico: NATO should be ready for ‘bad news’ from Ukraine, Stoltenberg warns 
‘We have to support Ukraine in both good and bad times,’ NATO chief says in ARD interview. 
NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg warned that the Western military alliance should be ready for bad news from the Ukrainian front as Kyiv continues to defend against Russia's all-out invasion. 
"Wars develop in phases," Stoltenberg said in an interview Saturday with German broadcaster ARD. "We have to support Ukraine in both good and bad times," he said. 
"We should also be prepared for bad news,” Stoltenberg added, without being more specific. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has finally caught up to what WNU has been saying since the collapse of Ukraine's counteroffensive this summer. Ukraine's front-lines are breaking (especially in the east), and there is now a very real chance of a Ukraine army collapse in the Donbas.

SIMI VALLEY, California — Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin offered a stark public warning to Israel on Saturday, saying the government there risks “strategic defeat” in Gaza if it doesn’t do more to protect civilians.
The comments came a day after the breakdown in negotiations over hostage and prisoner releases led to the resumption of the Israel-Hamas war. Austin told an audience at the Reagan National Defense Forum that if Israel doesn’t do everything possible to protect civilians, it might help “drive [Palestinians] into the arms of the enemy,” and would “replace a tactical victory with a strategic defeat.”

The Hill: White House warns it will run out of money for Ukraine unless Congress acts by end of year  
The White House sounded the alarm Monday that it will run out of money to provide weapons to Ukraine in its fight against Russia without congressional action by the end of the year. 
In a letter to congressional leaders, Office of Management and Budget Director Shalanda Young wrote the government is “out of money—and nearly out of time” to continue giving aid to Ukraine.The White House pleaded with Congress to act on a supplemental funding request first submitted in October, arguing it is of critical importance to U.S. national security.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The mood in Ukraine has definitely changed in the past few weeks. All of my contacts/friends/and family members are saying the same thing. They expect the U.S. will be abandoning Ukraine in the coming months. 
I have a different point of view. I predict the White House and Congress will find a way to continue to fund the war, and it may come this week .... US senators to be briefed on Ukraine this week amid heated negotiations on emergency aid (FOX News).

Reuters: Venezuelan voters reject ICJ jurisdiction over dispute with Guyana 
CARACAS (Reuters) - Voters in Venezuela rejected in a Sunday referendum the International Court of Justice's jurisdiction over the country's long-running territorial dispute with neighboring Guyana and backed the creation of a new state in the Esequibo region. 
The court has barred Venezuela from taking any action that would change the status quo in the area, but President Nicolas Maduro's government went ahead with a five-question "consultative" referendum.

All questions passed with more than 95% approval, according the electoral authority.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Venezuelan President Maduro is unpredictable. I expect more countries (besides Canada) issuing travel warnings in the coming days/weeks .... Canada issues updated travel advisory for Guyana amid border dispute referendum in Venezuela (CTV News).

articles.description:
Jordan Cohen, The Hill: Despite Washington’s confidence, US war with Iran would be disastrous 
President Joe Biden’s administration is publicly attempting to avoid a war with Iran, but American officials continue to fan the flames of war with incendiary rhetoric as the war in Gaza risks expanding into a broader regional conflict. 
For instance, on Nov. 26, Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) said the Biden administration needs to take a “massive retaliation” against Iran to end attacks on U.S. assets. Ultimately, congressmembers, the Biden administration, and former defense officials are all sharing sentiments that Washington could escalate its move toward armed conflict in the face of Iranian aggression.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: The economic disaster that would ensue with the closure of the Strait of Hormuz and a shutdown of almost a quarter of the world's oil supply will be incalculable. The U.S. is also not in a position to wage war against a foe like Iran. Military stockpiles and other resources are low due to the U.S. commitment to support Ukraine in its war against Russia, and Iran has spent years preparing itself in the event of an Israeli and/or U.S. attack. 
One should also not ignore the massive blow-back from U.S. allies who will be adversely affected by such a conflict. This is an easy prediction. A U.S. - Iran war will not receive the support from the West that the U.S. would want, unlike Iran who will be receiving enormous support from countries like China and Russia.
articles.title: Would A U.S. War With Iran Be Disastrous?

IDF spotters working at the IDF base in Nahal Oz. Credit: IDF Spokesperson's Unit © סופק על ידי Haaretz.com 
New York Times: Israel Knew Hamas’ Attack Plan More Than a Year Ago 
TEL AVIV, Israel — Israeli officials obtained Hamas’ battle plan for the Oct. 7 terrorist attack more than a year before it happened, documents, emails and interviews show. But Israeli military and intelligence officials dismissed the plan as aspirational, considering it too difficult for Hamas to carry out. 
The approximately 40-page document, which Israeli authorities code-named “Jericho Wall,” outlined, point by point, exactly the kind of devastating invasion that led to the deaths of about 1,200 people. 
The translated document, which was reviewed by The New York Times, did not set a date for the attack, but described a methodical assault designed to overwhelm the fortifications around the Gaza Strip, take over Israeli cities and storm key military bases, including a division headquarters.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Israeli and American officials are responding .... US and Israeli officials react to blockbuster report that Israel knew Hamas was planning attack (ABC News).
